## Introduction

<img src="images/scis_slides_logo.png" style="position: absolute; top: 10px; right: 10px; width: 300px; height: auto; z-index: 9999;"/>

### Significance

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em"}
-   Landslides refer to the geomorphic phenomenon of slope failure and mass movement.

-   In the last five decades, the frequency of landslide events has increased tenfold \[1\]

-   Despite comparatively lower casualty than other disasters, their impacts on urban development can be severely detrimental.

-   Commonly-used extensive engineering prevention works are costly and challenging.

-   Landslide susceptibility modelling enables decision-supporting for identifying highest-risk areas and conducting preventive measures
:::

<img src="images/landslides.png" height="350px/"/>

</section>

## Landslide Susceptibility Modelling Approaches

<img src="images/scis_slides_logo.png" style="position: absolute; top: 10px; right: 10px; width: 300px; height: auto; z-index: 9999;"/>

::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
::: {style="font-size: 0.7em"}
<h3 style="color: #FFC300">

Physically-based Modelling

</h3>

-   Analytical outcomes from physical and mechanical principles

-   Systeme Hydrologique Eropeen Transport (SHETRAN), TOPOG

-   **Uncertainties** mainly due to limited availability of spatially differentiated geotechnical data in real-world scenarios

<br> <br> <br>

<h3 style="color: #FFC300">

Expert-based Modelling

</h3>

-   Developed with the expert knowledge of local interactions between landslide occurrences and its controlling factors

-   Qualitative multicriteria analysis (Abella & Western); Heuristics based on index (Ruff and Czurda)

-   **Limited reproducibility or comparability** from one study to another due to subjectivity
:::
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
::: {style="font-size: 0.7em"}
<h3 style="color: #FFC300">

Statistical Modelling

</h3>

-   Estimate the relative spatial probability of spatial units aligning with future landslide incidents

-   Information Value (Thein, et al., 2023), Logistic Regression (Regmi et al., 2014; Sun et al., 2018), Maximum Entropy (Boussouf et al., 2023), Frequency Ratio (Wubalem, 2021; Ibrahim et al., 2021)

-   Reliance on numerical **abstraction** and statistical **assumptions**

<h3 style="color: #FFC300">

Machine Learning Modelling

</h3>

-   Learnt from trial-and-error without explicit programmed logic

-   Support Vector Machines (Ibrahim et al., 2021), Convolutional Neural Network (Wang et al, 2021), Random Forest (Kavzoglu & Teke, 2022), Decision Tree (Saha et al, 2021)​

-   **Limited interpretability and explainability** due to the model complexity
:::
:::
:::

## Study Area

<img src="images/scis_slides_logo.png" style="position: absolute; top: 10px; right: 10px; width: 300px; height: auto; z-index: 9999;"/>

::: columns
::: {.column width="40%"}
### General Information

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em"}
-   Valtellina Valley, located in the Central Alps of Northern Italy

-   Between 9.24°E to 10.63°E in longitude, and 46.00°N to 46.64°N in latitude

-   Total area of 3308 square kilometers

-   Characterized by a superimposed fluvial morphology and high, steep slopes, akin to typical alpine glacial valleys

-   Experienced significant damage and destruction caused by landslides such as the historic Valpola landslide and floods.

-   Surge in economic activities and human settlements (wine agriculture & ski-towns)
:::
:::

::: {.column width="60%"}
<br> <img src="images/landslide_inventory_map.png" width="950" height="auto" style="position: absolute; right: 0;"/>
:::
:::

## Data Pre-Processing

<img src="images/scis_slides_logo.png" style="position: absolute; top: 10px; right: 10px; width: 300px; height: auto; z-index: 9999;"/>

<br>

::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
<h3 style="color:#FFC300">

Data Extraction

</h3>

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em"}
-   Download DEM and Raster Images
-   Clip the DEM image to confine the study area
-   Run algorithms on QGIS, SAGA and ArcGIS Pro to extract topographic annd hydrological index values from DEM image
:::

<h3 style="color:#FFC300">

Data Wrangling

</h3>

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em"}
-   Recategorise vector layers (lithology, landuse landcover using R)
-   Raster vector layers (fault, stream, settlement) using R
-   Generate proximity maps using QGIS
-   Rescale and standardise the resolution of all the layers using QGIS
:::
:::

<br> <br> <img src="images/data_extractions_dem.png" width="3500"/>

Methodology

</h3>

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em"}

-   Create 15m by 15m grids per landslide sample point <img src="images/grids_screenshot.jpg" height="250px"/>

## Data Pre-Processing

<img src="images/scis_slides_logo.png" style="position: absolute; top: 10px; right: 10px; width: 300px; height: auto; z-index: 9999;"/> <br>

::: columns
::: {.column width="45%"}
<h3 style="color:#FFC300">

Zonal Statistic

</h3>

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em"}
-   Calculating zonal statistics for each variable for each landslide zone on QGIS using *mean* value for raster layers and *majority* for vector layers
-   Compiling all zonal statistics columns into a single dataset using R
:::

<h3 style="color:#FFC300">

One-Hot Encoding & <br> Binary Logic

</h3>

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em"}
-   Use one-hot encoding to convert categorical data into numerical data to fit for model training using R
-   One resultant column from binary assignment for each categorical variable removed to avoid complete or quasi-complete separation and variance inflation
:::
:::

## Correlation Matrix

<img src="images/scis_slides_logo.png" style="position: absolute; top: 10px; right: 10px; width: 300px; height: auto; z-index: 9999;"/>

::: columns
::: {.column width="40%"}
::: {style="font-size: 0.6em"}
Slope Angle Distribution
:::

```{r}
#| echo: false
pacman::p_load(sp, sf, st, spdep, raster, spatstat, tmap, devtools,vtable,ggplot2,egg, corrplot, patchwork, ggstats, ggstatsplot, GWmodel, tidyverse, gtsummary,vtable, sjPlot, sjmisc, sjlabelled, tableHTML, olsrr, car, blorr,ISLR, klaR,pROC)

valtellina <- read_sf(dsn = "data/vector", 
                      layer = "valtellina")
train_grids_v4 <- read.csv("data/aspatial/train_grid_v4.csv")

slope_angle <- train_grids_v4$Slope_Angle
quantile(slope_angle, probs = seq(0, 1, 1/4))

sample_Q1 <- subset(train_grids_v4,Slope_Angle < 18.41368)
new_train <- subset(train_grids_v4,Slope_Angle >= 18.41368)
sample_Q2 <- subset(new_train,Slope_Angle < 30.34639)
new_train <- subset(new_train,Slope_Angle >= 30.34639)
sample_Q3 <- subset(new_train,Slope_Angle < 38.54599)
new_train <- subset(new_train,Slope_Angle >= 38.54599)
sample_Q4 <- subset(new_train,Slope_Angle <= 82.91669)
#nrow(sample_Q1)
#nrow(sample_Q2)
#nrow(sample_Q3)
#nrow(sample_Q4)
ggplot(data=sample_Q3, aes(x= `Slope_Angle`)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=10, color="black", fill="#e9531e")
```

::: {style="font-size: 0.6em"}
Correlation Matrix Code
:::

```{r}
#| eval: false
set.seed(123)
ggcorrmat(
  data = sample_Q3[, 6:29],  
          matrix.type = "upper",
  type = "parametric",
  tr = 0.2,
  partial = FALSE,
  k = 2L,
  sig.level = 0.05,
  conf.level = 0.95,
  bf.prior = 0.707,
  ggcorrplot.args = list(
     tl.cex = 10, pch.cex = 5, lab_size = 3
  )) + 
  ggplot2::theme(
    axis.text.x = ggplot2::element_text(
      margin = ggplot2::margin(t = 0.15, r = 0.15, b = 0.15, l = 0.15, unit = "cm")
    )
  )
```
:::

## Variance Inflation Test

<img src="images/scis_slides_logo.png" style="position: absolute; top: 10px; right: 10px; width: 300px; height: auto; z-index: 9999;"/> <br>

::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
::: {style="font-size: 0.75em"}
| <b style="color: #FFC300;">Landslide Factors</b> | <b style="color: #FFC300;">VIF</b> | <b style="color: #FFC300;"> TOLerance</b> |
|-------------------------------------|-----------------|-----------------|
| Elevation                                        | 2.488950                           | 0.401776                                  |
| Slope Angle                                      | 1.596051                           | 0.626546                                  |
| Aspect (N)                                       | 1.837785                           | 0.544133                                  |
| Aspect (NE)                                      | 2.420200                           | 0.413189                                  |
| Aspect (E)                                       | 2.739139                           | 0.365078                                  |
| Aspect (SE)                                      | 2.914264                           | 0.365078                                  |
| Aspect (S)                                       | 3.200430                           | 0.312458                                  |
| Aspect (SW)                                      | 2.497585                           | 0.400387                                  |
| Aspect (W)                                       | 2.478521                           | 0.403466                                  |
| Profile Curvature                                | 1.316536                           | 0.759569                                  |
| Plan Curvature                                   | 1.624930                           | 0.759569                                  |
| Lithology (Metamorphic)                          | 4.437094                           | 0.225373                                  |
:::
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
::: {style="font-size: 0.75em"}

| Distance to Settlements                          | 1.733509                           | 0.576865                                  |
| Distance to Streams                              | 1.357373                           | 0.736717                                  |
| Distance to Road Networks                        | 1.871975                           | 0.534195                                  |
| Distance to Faults                               | 1.279720                           | 0.781421                                  |

| Average Precipitation                            | 1.242173                           | 0.805041                                  |
| TWI                                              | 2.548388                           | 0.392405                                  |

## Logistic Regression

<img src="images/scis_slides_logo.png" style="position: absolute; top: 10px; right: 10px; width: 300px; height: auto; z-index: 9999;"/>

::: columns
::: {.column width="40%"}
::: {style="font-size: 1em"}
-   Dichotomous/binary nature of the dependent variable (presence or absence of a landslide)
-   Independent variables can be either discrete or continuous, and are not required to satisfy normal distribution
-   Estimate the probability of landslide occurrences, with values ranging from 0 (absence of a landslide) to 1 (presence of a landslide)
:::
:::

::: {.column width="60%"}
<img src="images/log_reg_formula.png" width="1000"/>

::: {style="font-size: 0.75em"}
Logistic Regression Formula
:::
:::
:::

## Geographically Weighted Regression

<img src="images/scis_slides_logo.png" style="position: absolute; top: 10px; right: 10px; width: 300px; height: auto; z-index: 9999;"/> <br>

::: {style="font-size: 1.5em"}
-   Extends traditional and global regression frameworks such as OLS and LR by incorporating local parameters and spatial weights

-   GWR is used to capture spatial heterogeneity of different landslide factors by generating coefficient estimates which vary based on location

-   Calibrate the global LR model by assigning spatial weight to an observation determined by its proximity to location *i*
:::
